author: By Hannah Beech
title: Protests Shake Bangkok, Challenging Old Guard’s Grip on Thailand
description: The weekend rally heightened the focus on a once taboo issue: a rich and powerful monarchy that has rarely been challenged or criticized.
content: BANGKOK — The monsoonal showers did not stop them. Nor did the specter of 8,550 police officers, whose armed presence evoked violently crushed protest movements in Thailand’s past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Trump Wants to Cripple TikTok and WeChat. Why?
description: He says that they are a security threat. If so, it is time to show the world the evidence.
content: President Trump’s plan to severely restrict the popular WeChat and TikTok apps could be viewed as a tit-for-tat for China’s yearslong prohibition of American services like Facebook and Google. But I’d like to think we’re better than that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Presses for New Justice ‘Without Delay’ as Election-Season Battle Looms
description: The president is likely to nominate a successor this coming week to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday, but Senate Republicans are weighing whether they have the votes to confirm his choice before the Nov. 3 election.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump pressed Senate Republicans on Saturday to confirm his choice to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg “without delay,” setting up a momentous battle sure to inflame the campaign as he seeks to force through an appointment in the weeks before the election on Nov. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens, Jonathan Martin and Jon Hurdle
title: Wait or nominate? Many voters support doing what is best for their party, but for some, the court fight looms large.
description: In interviews with more than a dozen voters in battleground states on Friday night and Saturday morning, The Times found that Democratic and Republican voters were largely racing to partisan corners regarding how they think President Trump and Senate Republicans should proceed in filling the Supreme Court seat held by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: In interviews with more than a dozen voters in battleground states on Friday night and Saturday morning, The Times found that Democratic and Republican voters were largely racing to partisan corners regarding how they think President Trump and Senate Republicans should proceed in filling the Supreme Court seat held by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Curtis Rush
title: In These N.H.L. Playoffs, Backup Goalies Have Taken Center Stage
description: By the second round, six regular-season backups were functioning as No. 1s. One of them, Dallas’s Anton Khudobin, is in the Stanley Cup finals.
content: TORONTO — Several N.H.L. teams had a sudden conundrum in this postseason: They could not rely on their No. 1 goaltenders to get them through the two-month grind. They had to hope that their No. 2s could perform like a No. 1 and could come in cold if needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Death Revives Talk of Court Packing
description: The idea recalls a move by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who hoped to push older justices to retire.
content: The news on Friday that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg had died, creating a vacancy that could reshape the Supreme Court for a generation, revived talk about an idea that has been bandied about for years but, until recently, not feasibly considered by people in a position to enact it: court packing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Libby Peterson
title: Capturing the Faces of Climate Migration
description: A Times Magazine series examines how climate change will force millions worldwide to move. Recently, Meridith Kohut photographed people on the front lines of this shift. In America.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Patricia Mazzei
title: Trump Declares He Is Now ‘the Best Thing That Ever Happened’ to Puerto Rico
description: In announcing long-awaited aid for the storm-ravaged island, President Trump seemed to have his eye partly on the Puerto Ricans who now make up an increasingly critical voting bloc in Florida.
content: WASHINGTON — After back-to-back hurricanes ravaged Puerto Rico in 2017, President Trump was so resistant to spending billions of dollars to restore the territory that he suggested simply getting rid of it instead. “Can we sell the island?” he asked aides, according to a cabinet member who was there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Fatima Faizi and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Violent Attacks Plague Afghanistan as Peace Talks in Doha Slow
description: More than a dozen civilians are feared dead in an airstrike, as talks go on to finalize rules for negotiations.
content: DOHA, Qatar —  Violence continued unabated across Afghanistan on Saturday,  as negotiators from the warring sides remained bogged down by disagreements over a framework for talks a week after historic negotiations began in Doha.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Dissents were Ginsburg’s most memorable work on the Supreme Court.
description: There was a framed copy of the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009 on the wall of the chambers of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday. She counted the law among her proudest achievements, even as it illustrated her limited power. As part of the Supreme Court’s four-member liberal wing, she did her most memorable work in dissent.
content: There was a framed copy of the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009 on the wall of the chambers of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday. She counted the law among her proudest achievements, even as it illustrated her limited power. As part of the Supreme Court’s four-member liberal wing, she did her most memorable work in dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg: The Sorrow and the Worry
description: Readers express their sadness at the loss of the superstar justice but also worry about a rushed confirmation process with the election looming.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Ginsburg’s death revives calls for court packing.
description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death revived talk about an idea that has been bandied about for years but, until recently, not feasibly considered by people in a position to enact it: court packing.
content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death revived talk about an idea that has been bandied about for years but, until recently, not feasibly considered by people in a position to enact it: court packing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Roth
title: Colleges, Conservatives and the Kakistocracy
description: Universities with traditionally progressive ideals can welcome conservative views, and still reject authoritarianism and hate.
content: For the last several years I have been disputing overblown claims that political correctness is running amok on college campuses. Given my job as the president of Wesleyan University, well-known to be (happily) a bastion of left-leaning protest, this probably isn’t very surprising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Mount Wilson Observatory Survives a Trial by Fire
description: The birthplace of modern cosmology “has been declared safe” from the wildfires that have ravaged the surrounding area in Southern California.
content: Mount Wilson Observatory, where astronomers a century ago first described the expansion of the universe, appears to have survived a close call with the Bobcat fire, which has been ravaging the San Gabriel Mountains in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Nick Corasaniti
title: In the Most Litigated Election Ever, Early Democratic Wins but Few Clear Signals
description: Democrats won some important legal battles in the critical states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania. But the legal wars over the 2020 election are just getting going.
content: WASHINGTON — Ahead of an election that seems certain to have the most litigated voting rules ever, Democrats won important cases over the past week in the critical states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Denied the M.V.P., James Takes Out His Frustration on the Nuggets
description: LeBron James is playing angry and the Lakers are playing well. In Game 1, that spelled trouble for Denver.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — On one of his ferocious drives to the basket, LeBron James appeared to roll his left ankle as he tumbled to the court. He grimaced, relaced his sneaker as several of his teammates from the Los Angeles Lakers crowded around him and then walked with a barely perceptible limp to the free throw line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: On Racism and British Fashion
description: The designer Osman Yousefzada reflects on change in the industry, straddling cultures and why he looked beyond fashion to find his voice.
content: “I’ve always considered myself an outsider,” Osman Yousefzada said last week, sitting on a park bench near his home in North London. “Often, I’ve also been made to feel like an outsider, working in and around institutions and industries like fashion that are rooted in white codes and elitism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Quammen
title: The Pandemic, From the Virus’s Point of View
description: The career of the coronavirus so far is, in Darwinian terms, a great success story.
content: No sensible person can dispute that Covid-19 is a great tragedy for humanity — a tragedy even in the ancient Greek sense, as defined by Aristotle, with the disastrous ending contingent on some prideful flaw in the protagonist. This time it’s not Oedipus or Agamemnon. This time it’s we who are that cocky protagonist, having brought disaster on ourselves. The scope and the devastation of the pandemic reflect bad luck, yes, and a dangerous world, yes, but also catastrophic failures of human foresight, communal will and leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: At Tour de France, Memorable Duel Turns the Tables With One Day Left
description: For more than a week, Tadej Pogacar and Primoz Roglic had stalked each other across France. On Saturday, Pogacar surged ahead of his rival and seized the yellow jersey.
content: As Tadej Pogacar and Primoz Roglic each took their heads in their hands, seconds after completing Saturday’s penultimate stage of the Tour de France, neither man seemed to be able to process what had just happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Hundreds of Women Arrested at Protest in Belarus
description: Women have become the face of the protests against President Aleksandr Lukashenko, and his police force rounded up more than 300 participants in a “Women’s March” in Minsk on Saturday.
content: MINSK, Belarus — In a show of might, security forces in Belarus on Saturday arrested hundreds of women taking part in a protest march against the re-election of the country’s strongman, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Aleksei Navalny, Russian Dissident, Says He Can Walk and Speak Now
description: The opposition leader jokes that he has recovered enough from being poisoned to scroll Instagram and know where to put the likes.
content: Nearly a month after being poisoned with a nerve agent, Aleksei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, said he has recovered his ability to speak and walk down stairs. He has also regained what is perhaps his most potent skill — making acerbic posts on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Will the Election Turn on R.B.G.?
description: The nation was divided enough already.
content: WASHINGTON — I used to feel pretty optimistic that the country would get through the Trump years intact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jia Lynn Yang
title: Overlooked No More: Mabel Ping-Hua Lee, Suffragist With a Distinction
description: Lee stood out as a Chinese immigrant, giving speeches, writing articles and helping to lead a 10,000-strong march through the streets of New York City when she was just a teenager.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. It is also part of The Times’s continuing coverage of the centennial of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: From Trump, No Respect for Ruth Bader Ginsburg, or the Rules
description: Once a cheater, always a cheater.
content: I was prepared for Mitch McConnell’s hypocrisy, but his brazenness left me breathless. He pledged a speedy Senate vote on a Trump-nominated replacement for Ruth Bader Ginsburg less than two hours after news of her death broke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Will My Pandemic Loan Deferments Hurt My Credit?
description: For millions of American homeowners who have deferred mortgage payments during the crisis, the ability to borrow money again may depend on what type of loan they have.
content: Q: My partner and I are self-employed. We deferred our Wells Fargo mortgage payments for two months in case contracts disappeared during the pandemic. But our payments are now current. Will those deferred payments affect our ability to get a refinance? Can lenders hold it against us?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Make This Mustard-y, Shallot-y One-Pot Chicken
description: Make the most popular recipes of the week.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include chicken with shallots (above), Regina Schrambling’s Dijon and Cognac beef stew and Melissa Clark’s spiced ginger shrimp with burst tomatoes. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Pack a ‘Go Bag’ Now
description: The first step toward a solid evacuation plan is pulling together all the gear you need, before you need it.
content: Even if your home is far from the wildfires on the West Coast or the hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean, there may be other disasters that require you to leave with just a moment’s notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Smart Relative?
description: Robyn Weintraub plays us like a fiddle and leads us in singing a song of sixpence in this themeless puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Oh, joy! Robyn Weintraub is in the house, which guarantees a challenging solve full of sly, brain-busting clues, the kind you really appreciate once you finally apprehend them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Miami and Boston’s Young N.B.A. Players Are Bucking Tradition
description: Jayson Tatum and Bam Adebayo are just two of the young or less-experienced players making an impact in the Eastern Conference finals.
content: The conventional wisdom in sports has been that championship teams need to be stacked with experienced veterans — those less likely to buckle under pressure or make uncharacteristic mistakes with the game on the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Flames That Won’t Die Out So Easily
description: Conspiracy theories about antifa arson are a symptom of a deeper unraveling, and a sign of danger ahead.
content: YAMHILL, Ore. — The West has been burning, and one forest fire reached about five miles from the Most Beautiful Farm in the World, where I grew up here in the rolling hills west of Portland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim and Simbarashe Cha
title: From Bike Blockers to Street Medics: The Anatomy of an N.Y.C. Protest
description: Some demonstrators in New York have taken on informal but crucial roles over a summer of marches. Here’s how to spot them.
content: Only a few weeks after the first of what would become near-daily Black Lives Matter protests in New York City, Justina Heckard found herself on her bicycle in Brooklyn, leading a march in loose formation with other cyclists. An altercation with a driver left a protester injured, and Ms. Heckard and her fellow demonstrators decided they would need to sharpen their tactics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Dies: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: The news arrived late Friday night while Joe Biden and President Trump were both campaigning in Minnesota.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Avoiding Election Night Chaos
description: Readers offer ideas such as voting early or in person, and suggest what should be done if the president refuses to step down if he loses.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Nicholas Fandos
title: Cash Is Flowing Over Confirmation Battle for Supreme Court Vacancy
description: Justice Ginsburg’s death on Friday night plunged Washington into what is certain to be a fierce clash as liberals seek to stop President Trump and the Republican-led Senate from confirming a replacement before Inauguration Day.
content: WASHINGTON — Just hours after Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death was announced on Friday, the leaders of three of the left’s most potent advocacy groups, Demand Justice, Naral Pro-Choice America and Indivisible, were on a call with 1,000 progressive activists and strategists to begin to unfurl a plan they hoped they would not have to use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Raymond Zhong
title: After Trump’s TikTok Ban, China Readies Blacklist of Foreign Companies
description: Beijing issued rules that could allow it to halt exports, imports and investments by businesses accused of endangering national security.
content: BEIJING — As the United States and China trade blows over technology, Beijing on Saturday moved to create a blacklist of foreign companies seen as threatening its national security or acting against Chinese business interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Matt Stevens
title: Ginsburg’s Death Further Polarizes Voters Just Weeks Before Election
description: Republicans want to push forward. Democrats are seething. A bitterly divided nation gets more so as a Supreme Court nomination fight looms.
content: When Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg died on Friday, Marillene Allen, of Edina, Minn., worried that she would be mourning not just an admired jurist but democracy itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Shooting in Rochester Leaves 2 Dead and Over a Dozen Injured
description: The violence was the latest trouble for a city where law enforcement has come under scrutiny over the suffocation death of Daniel Prude, a Black man, in police custody.
content: A shooting at a backyard party packed with more than 100 people in Rochester, N.Y., killed two people and wounded 14 others in the early hours of Saturday, a police official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez reflects on Ginsburg’s legacy and says Biden should hold off on a list of judges.
description: Representative Alexandria-Ocasio Cortez, Democrat of New York, lamented that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg had spent her final days preoccupied by the “earth-shattering” political significance of her own death, criticized what she called the Senate majority leader’s ability to “manipulate the rules,” and urged Joseph R. Biden Jr. not to put out his own potential list of nominees for the Supreme Court vacancy at this moment.
content: Representative Alexandria-Ocasio Cortez, Democrat of New York, lamented that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg had spent her final days preoccupied by the “earth-shattering” political significance of her own death, criticized what she called the Senate majority leader’s ability to “manipulate the rules,” and urged Joseph R. Biden Jr. not to put out his own potential list of nominees for the Supreme Court vacancy at this moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Can Mitch McConnell Be Stopped?
description: If Republicans give Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s seat to some Federalist Society fanatic, Democrats should pack the court.
content: Two years ago at The Atlantic Festival, Senator Lindsey Graham defended the Republican decision to block President Barack Obama’s nominee to the Supreme Court, Merrick Garland. “If an opening comes in the last year of President Trump’s term, and the primary process is started, we’ll wait to the next election,” Graham said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Democrats shatter ActBlue’s donation records after Ginsburg’s death.
description: Democratic donors gave more money online in the 9 p.m. hour Friday after Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death was announced — $6.2 million — than in any other single hour since ActBlue, the donation-processing site, was started 16 years ago.
content: Democratic donors gave more money online in the 9 p.m. hour Friday after Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death was announced — $6.2 million — than in any other single hour since ActBlue, the donation-processing site, was started 16 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Zambello
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Loved Opera, and Opera Loved Her Back
description: Justice Ginsburg was the art form’s “greatest advocate and our greatest spokesperson,” says a leading director.
content: When Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death was announced on Friday evening, tributes quickly began flowing from an unlikely source: opera singers, who posted backstage portraits taken alongside Justice Ginsburg and testimonials to her intense love of their art form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: ‘Fifth Girl’ in 1963 Alabama Church Bombing Seeks State Restitution
description: Sarah Collins Rudolph lost her right eye at age 12 when a bomb went off at the 16th Street Baptist Church and killed four Black girls, including her sister.
content: Even though it has been more than 50 years since Ku Klux Klansmen bombed the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., Sarah Collins Rudolph said remnants from the blast could still be found in her body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Mourners Fill Supreme Court’s Plaza to Honor Ginsburg
description: At a spontaneous vigil in Washington, fans of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg celebrated her life and career, detached from the political moment.
content: WASHINGTON — Scores of people filled the steps leading up to the Supreme Court on Friday night, crowding the plaza outside and spilling across the street in a candlelight tribute to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died earlier in the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: McConnell Vows Vote on Ginsburg Replacement as Her Death Upends the 2020 Race
description: Democrats warn Republicans to follow the precedent they set in 2016, when they refused to consider President Barack Obama’s choice for the court on the grounds that it was an election year.
content: WASHINGTON — The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Friday instantly upended the nation’s politics in the middle of an already bitter campaign, giving President Trump an opportunity to try to install a third member of the Supreme Court with just weeks before an election that polls show he is currently losing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Ricin Is Said to Have Been Sent to White House
description: Letters with the lethal substance were also sent to local law enforcement offices in Texas, an official said. Investigators are trying to find out who sent them and whether more were circulating through the postal system.
content: WASHINGTON — Letters sent in recent days to the White House and to local law enforcement agencies in Texas contained the lethal substance ricin, and investigators are trying to determine whether other envelopes with the toxin were sent through the postal system, a law enforcement official briefed on the matter said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Adam Nagourney
title: Court Vacancy Injects New Uncertainty Into Rancorous Election Battle
description: After the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, it was not clear that President Trump’s right-wing coalition would be more motivated by a confirmation fight than the alliance of liberals and moderates supportive of Mr. Biden would be.
content: The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has put enormous new pressure on the two candidates in a presidential race already roiled by a global pandemic and a summer of civil unrest, raising the prospect of a contentious Senate confirmation battle waged side by side with the campaign. The skirmishing over a replacement is certain to thrust a constellation of red-hot issues — from abortion and gay rights to religious liberty and environmental regulation — to the foreground of national politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Samuel Jackson Traces the History of the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade
description: A docuseries on slavery through the lens of sunken slave ships that never reached their destination — ships that became mass graves of kidnapped Africans.
content: About two years ago, Samuel L. Jackson, the Hollywood titan, was presented with an idea to take part in a documentary about the trans-Atlantic slave trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Oswaks
title: Evan Rachel Wood Uses Her Roles to Heal
description: The actress finds catharsis in roles about pain and in her activism to help the survivors of domestic violence.
content: “A lot of my films echo what I have been through or what I was going through at the time,” said Evan Rachel Wood, 33, over Zoom from her Los Angeles home. “It’s almost like, subconsciously, you’re drawn to things you relate to, and then it becomes a really therapeutic and cathartic experience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: After Fire and Floods, Glimmers of Hope
description: Americans may be finding some common sense about building homes in vulnerable areas.
content: During the increasingly common ecological disasters that visit this country, there inevitably arises the hope that Americans and their elected politicians will learn from the experience, adopt new policies and provide for a less destructive future. We are now in such a period, with two unfolding climate-fueled disasters occurring at once: Savage wildfires in the West that have consumed more than five million acres of forests and scrublands and taken multiple lives in four states, and a Category 2 hurricane that has brought dangerous flooding and widespread damage to the Florida Panhandle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: As Bale Returns to Spurs, Only Perceptions Have Changed
description: A star’s war with Real Madrid has simmered for so long that the strangeness of it has been obscured. But his return to Tottenham doesn’t mean he’s finished as a player.
content: After a while, Gareth Bale almost seemed to relish it: the confrontation, the controversy, the opprobrium. It was as if he had stopped trying to fight it, wasting his energy correcting misunderstandings or railing at willful misinterpretations, and instead invited them to come crashing down on him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: AstraZeneca Releases Blueprints for Virus Vaccine Trial Amid Safety Scrutiny
description: A surge of infections in the Southwest and the Midwest is partly driving an uptick in cases nationally. The eight remaining members of the Supreme Court are expected to hear arguments next month via telephone.
content: AstraZeneca revealed details of its large coronavirus vaccine trial on Saturday, the third in a wave of rare disclosures by drug companies under pressure to be more transparent about how they are testing products that are the world’s best hope for ending the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Rachel Abrams
title: Nursing Homes Oust Unwanted Patients With Claims of Psychosis
description: They are finding what families say are pretexts to send patients to hospitals for psychiatric care — and then refusing to let them return.
content: In a New York nursing home, a resident hurled a bingo chip. At a home in Georgia, a 46-year-old woman, paralyzed from the waist down, repeatedly complained that no one had changed her diaper. In a California facility, a patient threw tableware.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: The Flight Goes Nowhere. And It’s Sold Out.
description: People who miss flying are rushing to buy tickets for flights that land in the same place they depart from.
content: In August, Nadzri Harif, a D.J. at Kristal FM radio station in Brunei, set foot in an airport for the first time in six months. The experience, he said, was exhilarating. Sure, moving through Brunei International Airport was different, with masks, glass dividers and social-distancing protocols in place, but nothing could beat the anticipation of getting on a plane again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Big Ten Football May Be Back. The Atmosphere Isn’t.
description: Athletes in other sports are still in limbo. Campuses have lost the campus feel. And people used to falls built around college football Saturdays are having to rethink their weekends.
content: The Big Ten plans to have football back after all in 2020. But the atmosphere of sports on its campuses?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg: Photos of Her Rise to the Supreme Court
description: Pictures capture moments in her legal career, from law school professor to associate justice on the high court.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 19, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 19, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about plans for coronavirus vaccine trials misstated the number of points at which an outside panel reviews data before a drug trial is complete at the drugmaker Pfizer. There are four such points, not three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: In ‘Power Grab,’ Health Secretary Azar Asserts Authority Over F.D.A.
description: Experts said the memo would make it more difficult for the F.D.A. to issue new rules, but it’s unclear how it would affect the vetting of coronavirus vaccines.
content: In a stunning declaration of authority, Alex M. Azar II, the secretary of health and human services, this week barred the nation’s health agencies, including the Food and Drug Administration, from signing any new rules regarding the nation’s foods, medicines, medical devices and other products, including vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Surviving Fashion’s Summer From Hell
description: Tibi is giving pandemic-era lessons in personal style, and finding new paths forward for its business.
content: In late April, Amy Smilovic began streaming live from the Instagram account of her fashion label, Tibi. About once a week, she and Dione Davis, her styling director, would put on Tibi outfits and talk — easily, authoritatively — about how the clothes made them feel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: McConnell vows to vote on Supreme Court nominee four years after blocking one.
description: Senator Mitch McConnell vowed late Friday that he would move to put President Trump’s nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court, breaking with his 2016 stance and setting the stage for a bruising battle that promised to reverberate through the 2020 elections.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell vowed late Friday that he would move to put President Trump’s nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court, breaking with his 2016 stance and setting the stage for a bruising battle that promised to reverberate through the 2020 elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Ginsburg’s Judicial Legacy of Striking Dissents
description: She was part of the Supreme Court’s 4-member liberal wing throughout her 27-year tenure and led it in her last decade.
content: WASHINGTON — There was a framed copy of the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009 on the wall of the chambers of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday. She counted the law among her proudest achievements, even as it illustrated her limited power. As part of the Supreme Court’s four-member liberal wing, she did her most memorable work in dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: The winner of the Arizona Senate race could be seated in time for a vote on a Supreme Court pick.
description: If Mark Kelly, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Arizona, unseats Senator Martha McSally, a Republican who was appointed to her seat and began serving last year, he could be sworn in as early as Nov. 30 — possibly in time to vote on a new Supreme Court nominee, elections experts said.
content: If Mark Kelly, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Arizona, unseats Senator Martha McSally, a Republican who was appointed to her seat and began serving last year, he could be sworn in as early as Nov. 30 — possibly in time to vote on a new Supreme Court nominee, elections experts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Reimposes U.N. Sanctions on Iran Over Objections of World Powers
description: The full range of the sanctions were announced on Saturday evening in Washington, but it is unclear how effective they will be.
content: WASHINGTON — Over the strenuous objections of its closest allies, the Trump administration reimposed United Nations sanctions against Iran on Saturday, though the weight of their repercussions is unclear without the cooperation of the world’s other major powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Rosenberg
title: Hi, There. Want to Triple Voter Turnout?
description: Campaign volunteers go door to door to rouse voters on Election Day. Now some stay outside polling places, asking voters to text friends to join in.
content: Turnout decides elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Susan Collins says she opposes holding a vote on a replacement for Ginsburg before the election.
description: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, said on Saturday that she was opposed to holding a vote on President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee before the November election, and suggested that were he to lose, his successor should ultimately choose a nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, said on Saturday that she was opposed to holding a vote on President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee before the November election, and suggested that were he to lose, his successor should ultimately choose a nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Adam Liptak
title: Leading Candidates to Fill Supreme Court Vacancy
description: President Trump has vowed to fill the vacancy created by the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg “without delay.” Here is who might fill the seat.
content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death on Friday created a Supreme Court vacancy that President Trump has vowed to fill “without delay.” He has issued four lists of potential nominees, the most recent one last week, and Mr. Trump said on Saturday that he expected to nominate a candidate in the next week, telling a campaign rally that night that  it “will be a woman.” Here is a look at some of the leading candidates on those lists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Albert Pujols Passes Willie Mays in Home Runs, if Not Dominance
description: Pujols’s 661st and 662nd homers are cause for celebration, and offer a chance to reflect on a career that took a wildly different trajectory than many of his elite peers.
content: Relegated to a part-time role for a basement-dwelling team, Albert Pujols — the man they used to call The Machine — stepped to the plate in the fifth inning of Friday’s face-off between the Angels and the Texas Rangers. The 40-year-old fell behind in the count, 1-2, before taking a mighty cut at a 91-mile-per-hour fastball, sending it 387 feet into the left field stands for his fifth home run of the season and the 661st of his career, passing Willie Mays for the fifth most in major league history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: In South Korea, Covid-19 Comes With Another Risk: Online Bullies
description: The country’s extensive response has been praised around the world but has led to harassment and slander, raising questions about privacy protections.
content: BUSAN, South Korea — The scandal that riveted South Korea’s online busybodies began when Kim Ji-seon checked into a beachside condominium in February. A 29-year-old office worker planning a June wedding, she had nothing more salacious in mind than meeting with members of her church to organize a youth program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: McConnell asks Republican senators to ‘keep your powder dry’ on the timing of a vote.
description: Senator Mitch McConnell implored fellow Republican senators on Friday night to “keep your powder dry” in an effort to stave off defections, as he weighed whether to force a vote on a possible replacement for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg before the Nov. 3 presidential election.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell implored fellow Republican senators on Friday night to “keep your powder dry” in an effort to stave off defections, as he weighed whether to force a vote on a possible replacement for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg before the Nov. 3 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maira Garcia
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg: The Films About Her Life
description: The Supreme Court justice, who died on Friday at 87, was a celebrated pop culture figure late in her life, and the subject of two films.
content: Ruth Bader Ginsburg was in her 80s when she took over the internet. Then came the movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Joe Biden’s Court Vacancy Plan: More Talk of Health Care and the Pandemic
description: Mr. Biden has spent months assailing President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus. With a bitter Supreme Court confirmation battle looming, he will seek to link the vacancy to the pandemic and the future of health care.
content: For months Joseph R. Biden Jr. has condemned President Trump as a failed steward of the nation’s well-being, relentlessly framing the 2020 election as a referendum on the president’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Wise
title: Tell Us: How Did Ruth Bader Ginsburg Influence You?
description: Share your photos and stories about what the esteemed Supreme Court justice’s career meant to you.
content: Ruth Bader Ginsburg was a generation’s unlikely cultural icon. Young women had her image tattooed on their arms; daughters were dressed in R.B.G. costumes for Halloween. “You Can’t Spell Truth Without Ruth” appeared on bumper stickers and T-shirts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Knew What to Do With Her Time
description: But she also knew something about the unreliability of happy endings.
content: “Now I happen to be the oldest,” Ruth Bader Ginsburg told me in 2015, when she was still 81 and I was asking her about retirement for a piece in this newspaper. “But John Paul Stevens didn’t step down until he was 90.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Puns and Anagrams
description: Dani Raymon bamboozles us.
content: VARIETY PUZZLE — Hello, and welcome back to another episode of “Does Deb Remember How to Do This?” My guest today is a Puns & Anagrams puzzle by Daniel Raymon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Legacy
description: In the rearview mirror, the victories of a trailblazing feminist. On the road ahead, the threat of an entrenched and powerful minority.
content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died Friday at the age of 87, will forever have two legacies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: A Republican senator argues a vote should not take place until after the election.
description: In a letter Friday night, Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, urged his Republican colleagues “to be cautious and keep your powder dry until we return to Washington.”
content: In a letter Friday night, Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, urged his Republican colleagues “to be cautious and keep your powder dry until we return to Washington.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Fires Scorch a Way of Life That Still Grows From the Trees
description: Oregon’s fate has always been intertwined with the forests that blanket the state. Now millions of trees are charred, and those who live from them face a future full of uncertainty.
content: MILL CITY, Ore. — The fire that galloped down the canyon along the North Santiam River last week charred tall firs to matchsticks and coated the survivors’ needles in dull, sepia-gray ash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Shadow of Merrick Garland Hangs Over the Next Supreme Court Fight
description: The fight over the confirmation of Judge Garland in 2016 set the tone for an even more brutal battle over who should succeed Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: WASHINGTON — On a Saturday evening in February 2016, just hours after Justice Antonin Scalia died during a hunting trip, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican majority leader, interrupted a Caribbean vacation to draw a line in the sand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger, Ronen Bergman and Lara Jakes
title: As U.S. Increases Pressure, Iran Adheres to Toned-Down Approach
description: The Trump administration has ramped up its criticism of Iran, but Tehran has chosen a path of restraint, intelligence showed.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has increased criticism and pressure on Iran in recent days: accusing the country of planning assassinations of American diplomats, announcing hacking indictments, preparing unilateral sanctions and denouncing Tehran for interfering in the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New Specter in the Smoky Air: Damage to Young Lungs
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 19, 2020.
content: “It is unethical to expose them and find out what happens 50 years from now. This does not look good for children.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Word Ladders
description: It’s a bit of a climb, but with Sam Trabucco to guide you, you’ll enjoy every step of your ascent. Or descent.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Several months ago, in my earliest days as a constructor (it’s still early days and will be for a long time) after exploring crossword forms in such classic texts as Patrick Berry’s $10 constructor’s guide, I decided to make a word-ladder puzzle with a theme set that represented the work-life balance, moving through the grid from WORK to LIFE.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: ‘A Titan of Justice’: Leaders React to Ginsburg’s Death
description: “Our nation has lost a jurist of historic stature,” Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said.
content: Political leaders from both sides of the aisle and the chief justice of the United States offered tributes to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday, remembering her as a trailblazer and a warrior for justice. But their comments also reflected what is expected to be a bruising fight over her replacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1895: French Hero Refuses Reward for Saving Lives
description: A man over the age of 60 was said to have saved more than 100 people from drowning. “I did my duty,” he said.
content: M. Rocher, commissary of police at Levallois, has, on the demand of a number of the inhabitants, opened an inquiry in regard to an old man popularly known as le père Harang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump’s Supreme Court Nominees List Gets New Scrutiny
description: The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg focuses attention to a list of potential court nominees that President Trump updated last week.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump, who counts his two Supreme Court appointments as among his greatest successes, last week issued a new list of 20 potential nominees to the court. There was no vacancy at the time, and the exercise seemed aimed at focusing attention on an issue that had helped secure his election in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: The Latest Positions of Key Senators on Ginsburg’s Replacement
description: The political jockeying intensified on Saturday about what the Senate would do to fill the vacancy on the U.S. Supreme Court.
content: It was nearly impossible on Saturday to separate the tributes to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg from the immediate political jockeying over whether Republicans will force through a nomination with just 45 days until the election, after refusing to do so for months after Justice Antonin Scalia died in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, David McCabe and Erin Griffith
title: Trump Approves Deal Between Oracle and TikTok
description: The approval delays President Trump’s threat to block a popular Chinese-owned social media app, while the American software giant, Walmart and others try to complete a deal to take control.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Saturday that he had approved a deal between the Chinese-owned social media app TikTok and major American companies, an agreement that will delay the U.S. government’s threat to block the popular app in the United States over national security concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Anchor the Week With Audre Lorde and Chinese Lute Music
description: You could also check out a Sims-inspired art show, get the expert take on Fashion Week or try a TrapAerobics class.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Ginsburg Expected to Lie in Repose at the Supreme Court
description: Plans for a commemoration and services have yet to be made final, but large crowds are expected to pay their respects for a justice who became a feminist icon and liberal hero.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is expected to lie in repose at the Supreme Court for two days, according to two people familiar with the preliminary plans, a public ceremony that is expected to draw large crowds of admirers who have come to view her as a feminist icon and liberal hero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Fandos
title: Trump and Pence push the Chamber of Commerce on Democratic endorsements.
description: President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence pushed officials at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in a phone call on Thursday for answers about why they have endorsed roughly two dozen freshman House Democrats, two people familiar with the discussion said.
content: President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence pushed officials at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in a phone call on Thursday for answers about why they have endorsed roughly two dozen freshman House Democrats, two people familiar with the discussion said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: On Venus, Cloudy With a Chance of Microbial Life
description: Astrobiologists shift their gaze, and speculations, to Earth’s broiling sister planet.
content: It’s been a while — like, forever — since anyone claimed to have discovered life on Venus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: For McConnell, Ginsburg’s Death Prompts Stark Turnabout From 2016 Stance
description: The majority leader pledged that President Trump’s nominee to replace Justice Ginsburg would receive a Senate vote, despite his 2016 move to block President Obama’s nominee in the waning months of his term.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell vowed late Friday that he would move to put President Trump’s nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court, breaking with his 2016 stance and setting the stage for a bruising battle that promised to reverberate through the 2020 elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Polls Have Shown Voters Prefer Biden to Pick Next Justice
description: In surveys before Justice Ginsburg’s death, he led by a slightly wider margin on choosing the next justice than he did over all against President Trump.
content: In 2016 and 2018, many analysts concluded that Supreme Court politics helped Republicans by helping to energize or consolidate conservative voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Best Sellers Sell the Best Because They’re Best Sellers
description: Publishing is becoming a winner-take-all game. Nobody dominates it like Madeline McIntosh and Penguin Random House.
content: On a Tuesday in mid-March, the most powerful executive in American publishing slid into a booth at a restaurant on Central Park South for her last power lunch of the pre-pandemic era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Canada’s Napa Valley Seeks Elusive Audience: Canadian Wine Drinkers
description: British Columbia’s wines are improbably being embraced by wine snobs around the world. But legal restrictions, and regional biases, are getting in the way at home.
content: OSOYOOS, British Columbia — The first surprise for Séverine Pinte, a French winemaker working in Canada, was how casual everyone was — more ripped jeans and flip-flops than Chanel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: In the Supreme Court Battle to Come, Here Are the Senators to Watch
description: Republicans hold a narrow majority in the Senate, meaning they can only afford to lose a few votes in their push to confirm a replacement for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Here are the potential swing votes.
content: WASHINGTON — The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has touched off a partisan brawl in the Senate to confirm President Trump’s nominee to replace her, a vote that Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, has vowed to hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Peru President, Martín Vizcarra, Survives Impeachment Vote
description: The effort by opposition lawmakers to remove Mr. Vizcarra failed on Friday, with Congress opting for stability as Peru deals with a devastating pandemic.
content: LIMA, Peru — President Martín Vizcarra of Peru survived an impeachment vote on Friday, ending a congressional battle which had threatened to plunge the country into a constitutional crisis amid a devastating pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Gen X, Right-Wing Bastion?
description: What it means that my generation is the future of the G.O.P.
content: If, as seems possible, Joe Biden wins the presidency by peeling away older white voters from the Republican coalition, liberals won’t just win the White House; they’ll gain a new generational villain to bemoan. Instead of laments about The Villages and sneers of “OK Boomer,” there will be a realization that the last bastion of conservatism in a leftward-shifting country may soon lie with my own Generation X.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Small Businesses Need Rent Breaks. But Landlords Are in Crisis, Too.
description: Some landlords are adjusting rent, while others hold firm. Their decisions are reshaping New York City’s neighborhoods.
content: After a laundromat in Manhattan said it could not pay its monthly rent in April and May, the manager of the property, Aaron Weber, asked for half the $7,200 bill. Mr. Weber allowed another struggling tenant in the neighborhood, an electronics repair store, to pay one-third of its $12,500 monthly rent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaitlyn Wells
title: Young Adult Dystopian Fiction That Feels Pretty Real
description: These four thrillers may be gussied up with future settings, but the problems they confront are rooted in today’s world.
content: SANCTUARYBy Paola Mendoza and Abby Sher320 pp. Putnam. $17.99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia Is Slow to Administer Virus Vaccine Despite Kremlin’s Approval
description: After announcing the first government clearance for a coronavirus vaccine, Russia delayed distributing it. It remains unclear how many people have received it.
content: MOSCOW — More than a month after becoming the first country to approve a coronavirus vaccine, Russia has yet to administer it to a large population outside a clinical trial, health officials and outside experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: ‘This Is Why We Wanted This Guy’: Conservatives Push Trump to Fill Court Seat Quickly
description: Social conservatives and evangelical groups sprang into action after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, encouraging a speedy confirmation and rallying support for embattled Senate Republicans.
content: Social conservatives and evangelical Christian activists began mobilizing over the weekend to push for the speedy confirmation of the person President Trump ultimately nominates to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, sensing that their long-denied goal of shifting the Supreme Court decisively to the right was finally within reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady, Katherine J. Wu and Sharon LaFraniere
title: AstraZeneca, Under Fire for Vaccine Safety, Releases Trial Blueprints
description: Experts are concerned that the company has not been more forthcoming about two participants who became seriously ill after getting its experimental vaccine.
content: AstraZeneca revealed details of its large coronavirus vaccine trials on Saturday, the third in a wave of rare disclosures by drug companies under pressure to be more transparent about how they are testing products that are the world’s best hope for ending the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Lost World War II Submarine Is Found in Southeast Asia
description: The U.S.S. Grenadier was scuttled in April 1943 after being attacked by Japanese bombers. Surviving crew members were tortured at a prison camp for more than two years, according to accounts.
content: In the murky waters of the Strait of Malacca, about 90 miles south of Phuket, Thailand, four divers discovered a World War II submarine that was scuttled 77 years ago, now teeming with marine life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Anne Stevenson, Poet and Plath Biographer, Is Dead at 87
description: Her poetry was acclaimed, but her take on her more famous contemporary caused controversy.
content: Anne Stevenson, a prominent poet whose 1989 biography of an even more prominent poet, Sylvia Plath, fueled the debate over Ms. Plath’s troubled life and her marriage to the poet Ted Hughes, died on Sept. 14 at her home in Durham, in northeast England. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: How Mitch McConnell Can Quickly Push Through Trump’s Supreme Court Nominee
description: The rules and partisan breakdown of the Senate make it possible for Republicans to swiftly confirm President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee. Here’s how.
content: WASHINGTON — Hours after the Supreme Court announced the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Friday, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, vowed that the Senate would vote on a replacement named by President Trump, setting up what is all but guaranteed to be a heated fight over the nation’s highest court that carries heavy political consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mourners Gather at Vigils Across the Country in Ginsburg’s Honor
description: The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the second woman appointed to the Supreme Court, has injected new uncertainty into the presidential election and set off a torrent of political maneuvering.
content: Americans paid their respects to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Saturday from the Supreme Court to the steps of her Brooklyn high school to courthouses across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Four Louisiana Officers Charged in Death of Black Man With Mental Illness
description: Prosecutors said a coroner had determined that Tommie McGlothen’s death in Shreveport in April was preventable because the officers should have known he needed medical treatment.
content: Four Louisiana police officers were indicted Friday on charges of negligent homicide and malfeasance after they used excessive force and a Taser to arrest a mentally ill Black man and then failed to give him medical attention, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Stephenson and Glenn Thrush
title: Democrats See a Glimmer of Hope Over Supreme Court Fight in Arizona’s Senate Race
description: If Mark Kelly wins a special election, he could end up casting a crucial vote on President Trump’s nominee.
content: TUCSON, Ariz. — Democrats have almost no power to stop a pre-election vote on President Trump’s nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court, but they see a glimmer of hope in a bank-shot scenario if they capture a Senate seat in Arizona in the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan and Karen Yourish
title: Ginsburg Supreme Court Vacancy Is the Second Closest to a U.S. Election Ever
description: The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Friday left an opening on the Supreme Court 46 days before Election Day.
content: The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Friday left an opening on the Supreme Court 46 days before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Bloch
title: Map: Tracking Tropical Storm Beta
description: A hurricane watch was issued for parts of the Texas coast.
content: A hurricane watch was issued for parts of the Texas coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Justice Ginsburg Is Mourned on the Supreme Court Steps
description: In the hours following Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death, people gathered on the steps of the Supreme Court to honor her life and legacy.
content: In the hours following Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death, people gathered on the steps of the Supreme Court to honor her life and legacy.
source.name: The New York Times
